Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Linking biotic interactions and environmental change to understand range dynamics of montane mammals over the past century
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human-based activities are rapidly changing natural environments on local to global scales, calling into question the persistence of ecosystems as habitats shift and species ranges collapse or move across the landscape. Species range shift predictions are routinely based on the direct impacts of climate change alone. But this approach is widely acknowledged as overly simplistic, excluding consideration of other abiotic and biotic factors. Understanding the complex interplay between environmental change and local ecological processes is needed to improve predictions. Paired modern and historical datasets provide a means by which suites of interacting factors affecting past range responses can be modeled and validated over multiple ecological and spatial and temporal scales. This project integrates community ecology, biogeography and biogeochemistry to address the impact of a century of environmental change on small mammals in the Great Basin, a highly threatened bioregion in North America. This project underscores the value of museum collections as ecological archives and will develop a new interactive multi-media exhibit at the Natural History Museum of Utah to highlight new uses for old specimens in ecology and conservation. Finally, this project supports women in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), as well as the interdisciplinary training of undergraduate and graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher.

Using paired survey data (80+ yrs separation) in Great Basin mountains, this project will determine what factors have mediated range boundary changes of small mammals. Alternate hypotheses will be evaluated regarding how the direct and indirect effects of resource use, species interactions, landcover, and climate change at the local scale have shaped landscape-scale species range dynamics. This mechanistic understanding will be developed within and across time periods, and results synthesized to identify the traits and contexts that heighten a species' sensitivity to environmental change. Structural equation modeling will investigate direct and indirect pathways through which biotic and abiotic factors affect species occurrence and abundance at local sites and range dynamics at landscape scale. Species distribution models will be used to hindcast past species ranges in altered climates. Stable isotope analysis will be used to infer differences in diet and habitat use over time, between mountain ranges, and in the presence/absence of competitors. Mammal stable isotope analyses will be done with museum specimens. This project will facilitate the training of a post-doctoral researcher and students as well as a museum outreach exhibit. The methods and findings will be highly generalizable to other groups and systems and will generate robust and transferrable predictions of how species and communities are likely to respond to future climate and land-use scenarios. Consequently, project results will be directly relevant to conservation and management regarding the role of biotic interactions and resource requirements in mediating responses to environmental change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human activities are rapidly changing the environment on local to global scales. As climate changes and habitats shift, species ranges may collapse or move across the landscape. Predictions of species? range responses are routinely based on the direct impacts of climate change alone. But this approach is overly simplistic, given a myriad of non-climate factors that have also shaped the landscape and thus affected species. This project evaluated how the direct and indirect effects of resource use, species interactions, landcover, and climate change at the local scale have shaped species range dynamics at the landscape scale. Specifically, our team paired modern and historical data on small mammals (e.g., voles, mice, and chipmunks) in the Great Basin, a highly threatened ecoregion in western North America, to identify the species attributes and environmental contexts that make a species most sensitive to environmental change. 

 

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

Our work demonstrates that small mammal species have not simply tracked changes in climate poleward or upward in elevation over the past century. Responses can be complex and reflect a number of factors including changes in the nature or strength of a species? association with specific climate variables over time. Interactions among species also influence their distributional limits and the resources (habitat and diet) that they use at a particular site. Simultaneously, changes in the resource base driven by climate and/or anthropogenic impacts also influence the distributional limits of species, which influence species interactions, making the direction of causality difficult to establish. We compiled a dataset of stable isotopes (13C, 15N, and 2H) from small mammal hair and plants that identifies the habitats and food resources used by species at a variety of sites in both the modern and historical time periods. This has allowed us to determine when changes in resource use results from changes in the environment versus changes in the presence/absence of a competitor species. Our focus on hydrogen as an isotopic tracer is rather unique and has been central to these efforts, providing a much greater understanding of how aridity has varied along Great Basin mountainsides both historically and today, and the impact of changing aridity on species distributions and thus interactions. We also examined change over time in the composition of small mammal communities distributed across the elevation gradient of Great Basin mountains. Although high elevations have experienced the greatest warming, communities there have remained relatively stable, while low elevation communities have changed markedly despite relative stability in the climate. These findings further highlight the importance of non-climate impacts on biodiversity, and the geographic scale at which those impacts are manifesting. Our examination of change in biodiversity also included a multi-dimensional perspective comparing the traditional measure of taxonomic diversity to functional and phylogenetic measures that capture the ecological and evolutionary similarities or differences among species. We found that the number of species alone is not a good estimate of the diversity of species present, and that communities at low and high elevations have both lost ecologically unique species. These losses may impact ecosystem functions and the ecosystem services they provide.  

 

Broader Impact Outcomes: 

Our study has provided numerous benefits to society beyond the enhanced data infrastructure and knowledge about biotic response to environmental change. Through the development of a multimedia interactive exhibit at the Natural History Museum of Utah, we have engaged the public (ca. 250,000 visitors a year) in the process of science, enhanced their understanding about the impacts of climate change and land use on biodiversity, and have imparted an appreciation for and understanding of the value of historical museum specimens in ecology and conservation. We also provided scientific and professional training to one postdoctoral researcher, four graduate students, and 16 undergraduate students (trained in field and/or lab techniques). Seven of these undergraduate students were also mentored through independent research projects and presented their findings at either a University-based or local/national scientific conference. Training in the communication of science is critical for many career paths in research, teaching, and conservation. To date, 2 PhD dissertations, one undergraduate honors thesis, and 7 peer reviewed scientific publications have resulted from this work, with 3 more currently in review and an additional 5 manuscripts currently in preparation.
